intro: Banisteriopsis amplectens, commonly known as the "Amazonian arrow poison vine," is a climbing plant native to the tropical rainforests of South America. It belongs to the Rubiaceae family and is characterized by its woody stems and heart-shaped leaves. The plant is notable for its production of toxic alkaloids, which have historically been used by indigenous peoples for making poison-tipped arrows. Its complex chemical composition makes it a subject of interest in both ethnobotanical and pharmacological research.
